\subsection{Problem 3}

\textit{A problem involving matrices or aligned equations.}

\textbf{Solution:}

We can write matrices:

\begin{equation}
\begin{pmatrix}1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 7 & 8 & 9\end{pmatrix}
\end{equation}

Or aligned equations:

\begin{align}
a &= b + c \
  &= d + e + f \
  &= g
\end{align}

\par\vspace{1em}

\subsection{Problem 4}

\textit{A proof-based problem.}

\textbf{Proof:}

We proceed by induction on

\begin{equation}
n
\end{equation}

.

\textbf{Base case:} When

\begin{equation}
n = 1
\end{equation}

, the statement holds because...

\textbf{Inductive step:} Assume the statement holds for

\begin{equation}
n = k
\end{equation}

. We show it holds for

\begin{equation}
n = k + 1
\end{equation}

...

Therefore, by induction, the statement holds for all

\begin{equation}
n \ge 1
\end{equation}

.

\begin{equation}
square
\end{equation}
